conclusion: Understanding the problem involves ensuring all light rays emitted by the source inside the glass sphere can pass through the sphere without exceeding the critical angle for total internal reflection.
The critical angle for total internal reflection at the boundary between two media is given by the formula involving the refractive indices of air and glass.
The critical angle is calculated as theta_c = sin^(-1)(1/n) using the refractive index of air (approximately 1) and the refractive index of glass (n).
For all light rays to pass through the sphere, the light source must be positioned such that the maximum angle of incidence at the boundary is less than the critical angle.
The maximum angle of incidence occurs when the light ray is tangent to the surface of the sphere, and the distance from the center of the sphere to the light source is denoted as d.
The maximum angle of incidence is given by theta_max = sin^(-1)(R/d), where R is the radius of the sphere and d is the distance from the center to the light source.
For the light to pass through the sphere, the condition sin^(-1)(R/d) < sin^(-1)(1/n) must be satisfied.
Taking the sine of both sides of the inequality, the condition becomes R/d < 1/n.
Solving for d, the condition becomes d > nR, indicating the light source must be located more than nR away from the center of the sphere.
The final answer is that the position of the point light source relative to the center of the sphere should satisfy the condition d > nR.
